newsitem.title: FRANCE: U.N. Sahara envoy James Baker meets Algerian minister.
newsitem.headline: U.N. Sahara envoy James Baker meets Algerian minister.

text.p: U.N. envoy for Western Sahara James Baker, who tours North Africa to relaunch the U.N. peace plan in the disputed territory, met Algerian Foreign Minister Ahmed Attaf on Friday, the official APS agency said.
"U.N. envoy James Baker held a working session with the Algerian Foreign Minister Ahmed Attaf attended by their delegations," the agency said. It gave no details.

Baker, who arrived earlier in Algiers, told reporters the visit in the region would enable him "to make suggestions" to the U.N. secretary-general on the necessity of applying or not the deadlocked peace plan in the territory, APS said.

The former U.S. secretary of state was appointed by U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan last month to try to resolve the dispute over the former Spanish colony. It is claimed by Morocco while the Algerian-backed Polisario Front seeks independence there.

The U.N. envoy arrived in Algiers from Morocco where he held talks with King Hassan, government officials and leaders of political parties on the U.N. peace plan and latest developments in the region, officials said.

A ceasefire in the Western Sahara, monitored by a U.N. force, has held since September 1991. But plans for a U.N. referendum on the future of the territory have been stalled since January 1992 over who is eligible to vote.
Baker, touring North Africa in a Spanish military airplane, will also visit Tindouf, the Polisario's rear base located in southern Algeria and Mauritania.
